Welcome to Wolfe! This documentation covers several aspects of Wolfe: 
an installation guide, an interactive tutorial on the core concepts 
of Wolfe, then a few examples of Wolfe applications. Please note that in many
cases the shown code can be edited and run directly in the browser. Feel free
to play around with these code snippets, but of course be considerate and don't
run large scale jobs on our server. 

Before you go on, please note that Wolfe is in a __very early__ stage, far from a 1.0 release. It will generally
be slow, break unexpectedly, give weird or no warnings etc., so use it at your own risk.

### What is Wolfe

Wolfe is a [probabilistic programming](http://probabilistic-programming.org/wiki/Home) 
framework aimed at simplifying the process of developing rich machine learning applications. 

Wolfe acknowledges that at the heart of most machine learning (ML) applications are two concepts:
mathematical models that assign probabilities or scores to hypotheses (or possible worlds),
and mathematical operators that interact with these models, most prominently maximization and
summation.

### Features

Wolfe is still in a very early stage, but
already comes comes with following features and abilities:

* Inference
    * Sum-Product Belief Propagation for marginal inference 
    * Max-Product Belief Propagation for MAP inference
    * [Dual Decomposition](http://cs.nyu.edu/~dsontag/papers/SonGloJaa_optbook.pdf) 
    * [Alternating Directions Dual Decomposition](http://www.ark.cs.cmu.edu/AD3/)
    * MCMC Sampling
    * Hooks for combinatorial factors (such as tree constraints), Structured BP.  
* Supervised Learning 
    * CRF style learning objectives
    * Perceptron style learning objectives  
    * State-of-the-art optimizers such as ADAGrad through the [FACTORIE](http://factorie.cs.umass.edu/) optimizer package. 
* Semisupervised Learning
    * Latent CRF style learning

### Name
The name Wolfe is a reference to [Philip Wolfe](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_Wolfe_\(mathematician\)), 
a mathematician considered to be one of the founders of [mathematical programming](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_programming). 
The name was chosen to reflect Wolfe's grounding in optimization: declaratively defining
objective and constraints, and optimizing such mathematical programs, is at the heart
of Wolfe. Moreover, Wolfe relies on decomposition approaches such as the 
[Dantzig-Wolfe Decomposition](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dantzig%E2%80%93Wolfe_decomposition). 

### Contributors
In alphabetical order:

* [Matko Bošnjak](http://matko.info/)
* [Jan Noessner](http://www.jan-noessner.de/)
* [Jason Naradowsky](http://people.cs.umass.edu/~narad/)
* [Larysa Visengeriyeva](https://twitter.com/visenger)
* [Luke Hewitt](http://lukehewitt.co.uk)
* [Sameer Singh](http://sameersingh.org/)
* [Sebastian Riedel](http://www.riedelcastro.org)
* [Tim Rocktäschel](http://rockt.github.io/)
* [Vivek Srikumar](http://svivek.com/)
